When you mentioned about soldiers, I thought about NERO. Perhaps 
something=
 like a HyperNEAT version of NERO can be created? It would 
be really inter=
esting. 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Julian Togelius" <julian@...> wrote=
:
>
> >  It does bring up an intriguing issue about role assignment in 
tea=
ms.
>  >  Is it best for each agent to have a fixed role that is assigned 
=
a
>  >  priori, or should roles constantly change based on position?
> 
>  =
Changing the roles based on position resembles the "virtual force
>  field"=
 or "potential field" control method, something that at least
>  used to be=
 common in some robotics application. In such methods, 
the
>  world is ove=
rlaid with a (ususally 2d) force field, where each 
point
>  has an associa=
ted vector that influences the movement of the robot.
>  Having obstacles e=
mit a repulsive field and targets an attractor 
field
>  solves some naviga=
tion problems elegantly.
> 
>  The big difference is of course that positio=
n-based multiagent
>  hyperneat encodes a complete behaviour rather than ju=
st a force
>  vector.
> 
> 
>  >  For example, in soccer, the roles are ass=
igned based on a kind 
of
>  >  virtual configuration of players that may n=
ever actually exist 
on the
>  >  field after the initial kickoff. As a res=
ult, if e.g. a forward 
drops
>  >  back momentarily to play defense, he do=
es not suddenly switch 
roles
>  >  and *become* a fullback. Rather, he goe=
s back to being a 
forward.
> 
>  On the other hand, in ant societies, I th=
ink at least some of the
>  role-switching (fight, gather food, feed the yo=
ung etc.) is done
> depending on where the ant happens to be
>  (relative t=
o breeding grounds, enemies, food etc.) rather than who 
it grew up
>  as. =
The same would go, I guess, for soldiers in a battle 
situation. I
>  guess=
 that in most scenarios, there are some aspects of any role 
that
>  are de=
fined a priori and some that are situation-dependent.
> 
>  By the way, it'=
s a very interesting idea, and a good paper!
> 
>  Julian
> 
> 
> 
>  >  Wh=
at would happen if your role in soccer switched 
instantaneously with
>  > =
 your position? Then the team could end up with problems where 
e.g.
>  >  =
everyone on the team becomes offense at the same time by 
accident
>  >  si=
mply because they momentarily moved up the field. Then who 
will go
>  >  b=
ack to defend? It seems there is a use to roles defined a 
priori.
>  >
>  =
>  Yet I imagine in other domains role makes more sense based on 
current
>=
  >  position alone. So it is probably domain-dependent, and an
>  >  inter=
esting issue to think about.
>  >
>  >  ken

dependin=
g on

o=
n the
>  >  > field? It would require a great deal of computation time (it =

has to

it may

>  >  > > controlling multiple heterogeneous agents in this new
>  >  > >=
 paper, "Generative Encoding for Multiagent Learning," to 
appear at
>  >  =
> > GECCO 2008:

>  >=

option=3Dcom_content&task=3Dview&id=3D14&Itemid=3D28#dambrosio.gecco=
08

.edu/papers/dambrosio_gecco08.pdf

ample of videos that depict various 
evolved
>  >  > > teams in action:
>  =

>  >  > >
>  >=
  > > The interesting idea in this paper is that just as a single
>  >  > >=
 connective CPPN can encode how a single network varies over 
space,
>  >  =
> > it can also encode how a *set* of networks (each 
representing the
>  >=
  > > policy of one agent on the team) varies over space. In this 
way,
>  =
>  > > HyperNEAT can learn an expression that encodes how policies 
vary
> =
 >  > > over the team geometry. For example, in a soccer team 
agents vary
=
>  >  > > from defensive to offensive as you move away from the goal. 
Part=

>  >  > of
>  >  > > the power of this approach is that it means basic ski=
lls 
can be
>  >  > > learned and shared among the whole team, since the CP=
PN 
encodes how
>  >  > > those skills vary across the field.
